qas.question: At what time was tectonic formation mild?
Where did the basic geological changes of this period occur?
What supercontinent split to form two smaller continents?
What was the northern continent split from Pangaea?
What was Pangaea's southern continent called?
At what time was tectonic formation especially active?
What was the northern continent that combined into Pangaea?
What continent split to destroy the passive continental margin near the Atlantic?

context: Compared to the vigorous convergent plate mountain-building of the late Paleozoic, <a0_0><b5_0>Mesozoic<b5_0/><a0_0/> tectonic deformation was comparatively mild. The sole major <b8_0>Mesozoic orogeny<b8_0/> occurred in what is now the <a1_0>Arctic<a1_0/>, creating the Innuitian orogeny, the Brooks Range, the Verkhoyansk and Cherskiy Ranges in Siberia, and the Khingan Mountains in Manchuria. This orogeny was related to the opening of the Arctic Ocean and subduction of the North China and Siberian cratons under the Pacific Ocean. Nevertheless, the era featured the dramatic rifting of the supercontinent Pangaea. <a2_0><b7_0>Pangaea<b7_0/><a2_0/> gradually split into a northern continent, <a3_0><b6_0>Laurasia<b6_0/><a3_0/>, and a southern continent, <a4_0>Gondwana<a4_0/>. This created the passive continental margin that characterizes most of the Atlantic coastline (such as along the U.S. East Coast) today.
